instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3302: What is 820-3302? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
Led501 ON

<SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.09V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.416V
<SIGNAL>PP12V_S5</SIGNAL>: 12.09V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 4.979V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.294V

No S4 State when triggering the power button.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> not pulsing when trigger on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 3.416V

I'm suspecting the PSU but I don't have a spare one to test.....
I just wanted to make sure that the issue is not coming from the board itself before ordering a new PSU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
Why PSU, if delivers 12V?

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts (drop pulse) triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
Use J5020 pads, instead of external power button.
Don't forget to check RTC signals.
Remove CMOS coin cell, board should then start by itself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
Yes the PSU delivers 12V, but we only need 12V? , no other signal like <SIGNAL>SMC_ACDC_ID</SIGNAL>?

With the CMOS coin cell removed:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.295V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts (drop from 3.404V to 0.340V) when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> by shorting C600

But still the board doesn't start ( fan not spinning )....

Also tried SMC bypass mode.....no effect except led is delayed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message: On these usually shorted USB, check that first.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message: Checked all RX N/P  TX N/P of all 4 usb ports none of them is shorted to Gnd

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
Sorry,

but none of the 4 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_EXT</SIGNAL> is shorted to gnd they all mesure around 0.500V in diode mode to gnd

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message: but at L7650 Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>) I'm mesuring 0.148V in diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, check for reaction at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time.

"Don't forget to check RTC signals."
Is OK you've checked RTC power, but I was talking about ALL (4) RTC signals...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
All good.

"If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, check for reaction at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals at same time."
Any comment???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
When I short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to gnd, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> react and drops to 0.3V but none of the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>/4/3 reacts they just mesure 0V

dead <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>? or ,need a reflow?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_PCH_L</SIGNAL>?
If OK, then looks like bad PCH.
You can try a reflow, just in case crap accumulated underneath PCH.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_PCH_L</SIGNAL> is solid and mesuring 2.88V and never drops when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3302</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not turning ON
threads.message: Reflowed PCH same issue......dead PCH I guess
